Award.AwardTitle: SG: Synthetic analysis of the importance of species richness to ecosystem services in natural systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nature provides ecosystem services that benefit humans: crops rely on pollinators, marshes protect coasts from storm surges, and forests remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. The world is rapidly losing biodiversity, and understanding how biodiversity loss will affect ecosystem services is important for human well-being. Most attempts to do this have used experiments in the field and laboratory. Natural communities, in which ecosystem services are provided, rarely look like experiments. Scientists acknowledge this, but it has been hard to study the effect of biodiversity loss on ecosystem services in the real world, in large part because of limitations in the analysis of complex natural communities. In this project, the researchers will use a new method that overcomes previous limitations to analyze some of the world's largest data sets, with the goal of understanding what aspects of natural communities are needed for ecosystem services. For example, is it enough to have many individuals of a few species, or do we need many different species to provide ecosystem services? This research will provide society benefits through a better understanding of how biodiversity influences ecosystem function, which could have relevance for science policy. Additionally, data and coding from the project will be made available to the public.

Knowledge of what drives ecosystem services at large scales is rudimentary, and the widespread belief that species richness is necessary for ecosystem services in natural systems is more of an assumption than an established fact. This project will use a novel and powerful analytical approach, based on the Price equation from evolutionary biology, to determine the importance of biodiversity to multiple ecosystem services. Specifically, the Price equation partitions differences in ecosystem services into three additive terms: richness, composition, and context dependence (which includes abundance variation as well as environmental factors). The PIs will compile the largest and most complete publicly-available data sets, and use them to conduct a synthetic analysis. The research will determine: (1) the relative importance of richness, composition, and context dependence in producing the mean levels and temporal variance of ecosystem services, (2) the role of spatial and temporal scale in ecosystem functions, and (3) the extent to which data from the worlds' largest biodiversity-function experiments align with results from ecosystems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Human societies depend on functions provided by ecosystems, such as pollination, carbon storage, and many others. These ecosystem functions are provided by Earth’s most unique feature: living organisms and their incredible diversity. Biodiversity is changing as some species go extinct and invasive species spread, and there is a natural urge to understand how these changes will affect ecosystem functions. Hundreds of controlled experiments have shown that species loss reduces ecosystem function. However, we know much less about how biodiversity affects ecosystem functions in nature. In this project, the researchers showed that studies done in experiments and nature reach different conclusions about how much species loss affects ecosystem function. Specifically, species loss had greater effects in experiments than in nature. This distinction was due to experiments enforcing random species loss by design, while in nature lost species tended to be rare species with low contributions to ecosystem function. The results of this work help explain longstanding differences between the apparent importance of biodiversity in experiments and natural communities. In a follow-up project, the researchers developed a new analytical tool that can be used to understand how losses of individual organisms, rather than species, affect ecosystem function. This is a useful advance because changes in abundance are easier to measure than changes in richness, abundance is more sensitive to global change than richness, and large declines in abundance can precede any species loss.

Broader Impacts

The researchers developed and made freely available new analytical tools, focused on making a specific analysis (the ecological Price equation) much more accessible to other ecologists. These include a new standardization method and an R function for the richness-based ecological Price equation, and an R function for the abundance-based ecological Price equation. Results were communicated to other scientists by the PI, co-PI, and postdoc at national meetings and several universities (Ecological Society of America Annual Meeting, University of Calgary, University of California – Davis, and the University of Louisiana at Lafayette). The researchers also gave outreach presentations to local groups, including the Acadiana Native Plant Project, and worked as scientific advisors on a bee photography exhibit at the Hilliard Art Museum in Lafayette, Louisiana. In both cases, the researchers discussed the importance of native bee biodiversity for pollination and gave advice on practices that can make residential areas and working lands more suitable for insect wildlife. Unfortunately, two thirds of the grant period was during the COVID-19 pandemic and other planned outreach activities had to be cancelled.
